required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: A Retrospective Review of FloSeal Use in Total Shoulder Arthroplasty
clinical_study.official_title: A Retrospective Review of FloSeal Use in Total Shoulder Arthroplasty

lead_sponsor.agency: Western Orthopaedics Research and Education Foundation

clinical_study.source: Western Orthopaedics Research and Education Foundation

oversight_info.authority: United States: Food and Drug Administration

brief_summary.textblock: The proposed study aims to objectively assess 2-year clinical and radiographic results for the rate of glenoid component loosening in total shoulder arthroplasty (TSA). This retrospective radiographic review will provide evidence for equivalence or superiority in curtailing loosening, a known complication in arthroplasty, when a hemostatic agent is utilized in conjunction with cement at the glenoid.

clinical_study.study_design: Observational Model: Cohort, Time Perspective: Retrospective

primary_outcome.description: Radiographic loosening is defined by the presence of radiolucent lines at the bone-cement interface at 2 years. Lines are measured as being either not-present, less than 2mm or greater than/equal to 2mm, in addition to implant seating and the radiodensity between the flanges of the central peg.

study_pop.textblock: Patients who have previously undergone anatomic total shoulder arthroplasty for the treatment of glenohumeral osteoarthritis.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patients must have completed at least 2 years follow-up following their total shoulder replacement
- Patients must have had radiographic imaging obtained at that 2 years
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patients less than 21 years of age
- Patients who have been imprisoned since the time of surgery
- Patients who are mentally impaired
